sentences.text: THE ISSUES

rhetClass.text: THE ISSUES

sentences.text: Entitlement to a rating in excess of 10 percent for service-connected boutonniere deformity of the left index finger.

rhetClass.text: Entitlement to a rating in excess of 10 percent for service-connected boutonniere deformity of the left index finger.

sentences.text: Entitlement to service connection for a left hand disability, to include as secondary to service-connected left index finger disability.

rhetClass.text: Entitlement to service connection for a left hand disability, to include as secondary to service-connected left index finger disability.

sentences.text: Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

rhetClass.text: Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

sentences.text: Propriety of reduction of service-connected hearing loss from 10 to zero percent, effective May 18, 2010.

rhetClass.text: Propriety of reduction of service-connected hearing loss from 10 to zero percent, effective May 18, 2010.

sentences.text: INTRODUCTION

rhetClass.text: INTRODUCTION

sentences.text: The record reflects the Veteran served on active duty in the United States Air Force from November 1975 to November 1979.

rhetClass.text: The record reflects the Veteran served on active duty in the United States Air Force from November 1975 to November 1979.

sentences.text: Further, the record reflects he had additional service in the Reserves.

rhetClass.text: Further, the record reflects he had additional service in the Reserves.

sentences.text: This matter is before the Board of Veterans' Appeals (Board) on appeal from rating decisions by a Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO).

rhetClass.text: This matter is before the Board of Veterans' Appeals (Board) on appeal from rating decisions by a Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO).

sentences.text: This appeal has been advanced on the Board's docket pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 20.900(c) (2017).

rhetClass.text: This appeal has been advanced on the Board's docket pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 20.900(c) (2017).

sentences.text: The Veteran provided testimony at a hearing before the undersigned Veterans Law Judge (VLJ) in December 2017.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran provided testimony at a hearing before the undersigned Veterans Law Judge (VLJ) in December 2017.

sentences.text: A transcript of that hearing is of record.

rhetClass.text: A transcript of that hearing is of record.

sentences.text: For the reasons addressed in the REMAND portion of the decision below, the Board finds that, except for the psychiatric disorder claim, further development is required regarding the Veteran's appellate claims.  Accordingly, these claims are REMANDED to the Agency of Original Jurisdiction (AOJ).

rhetClass.text: For the reasons addressed in the REMAND portion of the decision below, the Board finds that, except for the psychiatric disorder claim, further development is required regarding the Veteran's appellate claims.  Accordingly, these claims are REMANDED to the Agency of Original Jurisdiction (AOJ).

sentences.text: FINDINGS OF FACT

rhetClass.text: FINDINGS OF FACT

sentences.text: The competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.

rhetClass.text: The competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.

polarity.text: The competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.

ruleID.text: The competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.

sentences.text: CONCLUSION OF LAW

rhetClass.text: CONCLUSION OF LAW

sentences.text: The criteria for a grant of service connection for PTSD are met.

rhetClass.text: The criteria for a grant of service connection for PTSD are met.

sentences.text: REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSION

rhetClass.text: REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSION

sentences.text: Establishing service connection generally requires medical or, in certain circumstances, lay evidence of (1) a current disability; (2) an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a nexus between the claimed in-service disease or injury and the present disability.

rhetClass.text: Establishing service connection generally requires medical or, in certain circumstances, lay evidence of (1) a current disability; (2) an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a nexus between the claimed in-service disease or injury and the present disability.

sentences.text: See Davidson v. Shinseki, 581 F.3d 1313 (Fed. Cir. 2009); Hickson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 247, 253 (1999); Caluza v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 498, 506 (1995), aff'd per curiam, 78 F. 3d 604 (Fed. Cir. 1996) (table).

rhetClass.text: See Davidson v. Shinseki, 581 F.3d 1313 (Fed. Cir. 2009); Hickson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 247, 253 (1999); Caluza v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 498, 506 (1995), aff'd per curiam, 78 F. 3d 604 (Fed. Cir. 1996) (table).

sentences.text: In addition to the general rules of service connection noted above, service connection for PTSD requires medical evidence diagnosing the condition in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 (a); a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor; and credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred.

rhetClass.text: In addition to the general rules of service connection noted above, service connection for PTSD requires medical evidence diagnosing the condition in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 (a); a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor; and credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred.

sentences.text: Further, 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 (a) requires that diagnoses of mental disorders conform to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM).

rhetClass.text: Further, 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 (a) requires that diagnoses of mental disorders conform to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM).

sentences.text: The law also provides that if the evidence establishes a diagnosis of PTSD during service and the claimed stressor is related to that service, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided that the claimed stressor is consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of the veteran's service, the veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.

rhetClass.text: The law also provides that if the evidence establishes a diagnosis of PTSD during service and the claimed stressor is related to that service, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided that the claimed stressor is consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of the veteran's service, the veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.

sentences.text: Determinations as to service connection will be based on review of the entire evidence of record, to include all pertinent medical and lay evidence, with due consideration to VA's policy to administer the law under a broad and liberal interpretation consistent with the facts in each individual case.

rhetClass.text: Determinations as to service connection will be based on review of the entire evidence of record, to include all pertinent medical and lay evidence, with due consideration to VA's policy to administer the law under a broad and liberal interpretation consistent with the facts in each individual case.

sentences.text: In this case, the Board acknowledges that an April 2017 VA examination concluded the Veteran does not currently satisfy the DSM criteria for a diagnosis of PTSD.

rhetClass.text: In this case, the Board acknowledges that an April 2017 VA examination concluded the Veteran does not currently satisfy the DSM criteria for a diagnosis of PTSD.

sentences.text: However, the examiner also stated that the Veteran may have had PTSD in the past.

rhetClass.text: However, the examiner also stated that the Veteran may have had PTSD in the past.

sentences.text: The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims (Court) held in McClain v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 319 (2007) that the requirement that a claimant have a current disability before service connection may be awarded for that disability is also satisfied when a claimant has a disability at the time a claim for VA disability compensation is filed or during the pendency of that claim, even if no disability is present at the time of the claim's adjudication.

rhetClass.text: The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims (Court) held in McClain v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 319 (2007) that the requirement that a claimant have a current disability before service connection may be awarded for that disability is also satisfied when a claimant has a disability at the time a claim for VA disability compensation is filed or during the pendency of that claim, even if no disability is present at the time of the claim's adjudication.

sentences.text: Here, a review of the medical treatment records reflect the Veteran has been diagnosed with PTSD during the pendency of this case, to include in 2010 and 2011.

rhetClass.text: Here, a review of the medical treatment records reflect the Veteran has been diagnosed with PTSD during the pendency of this case, to include in 2010 and 2011.

sentences.text: Moreover, the law mandates resolving all reasonable doubt in favor of the Veteran.

rhetClass.text: Moreover, the law mandates resolving all reasonable doubt in favor of the Veteran.

sentences.text: The Board further notes that the Veteran has essentially contended he has PTSD due to the in-service stressors of participating in rescue operations of a crashed airplane, and witnessing the aftermath of the Jonestown massacre.

rhetClass.text: The Board further notes that the Veteran has essentially contended he has PTSD due to the in-service stressors of participating in rescue operations of a crashed airplane, and witnessing the aftermath of the Jonestown massacre.

sentences.text: Regarding these stressors, the record reflects the Veteran was part of the 1550th Organization Maintenance Squadron, 1550 Aircrew Training and Test Wing; which Department of Personnel Records Information Retrieval System (DPRIS) has confirmed did participate in operations consistent with the stressors identified by the Veteran.

rhetClass.text: Regarding these stressors, the record reflects the Veteran was part of the 1550th Organization Maintenance Squadron, 1550 Aircrew Training and Test Wing; which Department of Personnel Records Information Retrieval System (DPRIS) has confirmed did participate in operations consistent with the stressors identified by the Veteran.

sentences.text: Granted, it has been noted that the record does not confirm the Veteran personally participated in either of these operations.

rhetClass.text: Granted, it has been noted that the record does not confirm the Veteran personally participated in either of these operations.

sentences.text: Nevertheless, as he was a member of that group, his purported participation is not incompatible with his military occupational specialty (MOS), and in absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, the Board finds the Veteran's account of such stressors is consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of his active service.

rhetClass.text: Nevertheless, as he was a member of that group, his purported participation is not incompatible with his military occupational specialty (MOS), and in absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, the Board finds the Veteran's account of such stressors is consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of his active service.

polarity.text: Nevertheless, as he was a member of that group, his purported participation is not incompatible with his military occupational specialty (MOS), and in absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, the Board finds the Veteran's account of such stressors is consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of his active service.

ruleID.text: Nevertheless, as he was a member of that group, his purported participation is not incompatible with his military occupational specialty (MOS), and in absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, the Board finds the Veteran's account of such stressors is consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of his active service.

sentences.text: The Board also acknowledges that the April 2017 VA examiner provided an opinion against the Veteran's current acquired psychiatric disorder being etiologically related to his active service.

rhetClass.text: The Board also acknowledges that the April 2017 VA examiner provided an opinion against the Veteran's current acquired psychiatric disorder being etiologically related to his active service.

sentences.text: However, various medical treatment records indicate otherwise.

rhetClass.text: However, various medical treatment records indicate otherwise.

sentences.text: In pertinent part, an initial intake assessment for PTSD in December 2011 shows a diagnosis of PTSD, and indicated it was based upon the Veteran's account of the aforementioned stressors.

rhetClass.text: In pertinent part, an initial intake assessment for PTSD in December 2011 shows a diagnosis of PTSD, and indicated it was based upon the Veteran's account of the aforementioned stressors.

sentences.text: As such, it appears the competent medical evidence is in equipoise on this matter.

rhetClass.text: As such, it appears the competent medical evidence is in equipoise on this matter.

sentences.text: In Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49, 54 (1990), the Court stated that in light of the benefit of the doubt doctrine, the question is whether the evidence supports the claim or is in relative equipoise, with the claimant prevailing in either event.

rhetClass.text: In Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49, 54 (1990), the Court stated that in light of the benefit of the doubt doctrine, the question is whether the evidence supports the claim or is in relative equipoise, with the claimant prevailing in either event.

sentences.text: In view of the foregoing, the Board finds the competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.

rhetClass.text: In view of the foregoing, the Board finds the competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.

polarity.text: In view of the foregoing, the Board finds the competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.

ruleID.text: In view of the foregoing, the Board finds the competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.

sentences.text: Therefore, service connection is warranted.

rhetClass.text: Therefore, service connection is warranted.

sentences.text: The Board acknowledges that the Veteran has received various diagnoses for his acquired psychiatric disorder in addition to PTSD, to include mood disorder, adjustment disorder, and depressive disorder; and the law does not preclude establishing service connection for a separately diagnosed acquired psychiatric disorder.

rhetClass.text: The Board acknowledges that the Veteran has received various diagnoses for his acquired psychiatric disorder in addition to PTSD, to include mood disorder, adjustment disorder, and depressive disorder; and the law does not preclude establishing service connection for a separately diagnosed acquired psychiatric disorder.

polarity.text: The Board acknowledges that the Veteran has received various diagnoses for his acquired psychiatric disorder in addition to PTSD, to include mood disorder, adjustment disorder, and depressive disorder; and the law does not preclude establishing service connection for a separately diagnosed acquired psychiatric disorder.

ruleID.text: The Board acknowledges that the Veteran has received various diagnoses for his acquired psychiatric disorder in addition to PTSD, to include mood disorder, adjustment disorder, and depressive disorder; and the law does not preclude establishing service connection for a separately diagnosed acquired psychiatric disorder.

sentences.text: See Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1 (2009).

rhetClass.text: See Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1 (2009).

sentences.text: However, based upon review of the treatment records associated with the diagnosis of PTSD, the Board finds this condition encompasses the scope of the Veteran's psychiatric symptomatology.

rhetClass.text: However, based upon review of the treatment records associated with the diagnosis of PTSD, the Board finds this condition encompasses the scope of the Veteran's psychiatric symptomatology.

sentences.text: Thus, the grant of service connection for PTSD constitutes a full grant of the benefits sought on appeal with respect to this claim.

rhetClass.text: Thus, the grant of service connection for PTSD constitutes a full grant of the benefits sought on appeal with respect to this claim.

polarity.text: Thus, the grant of service connection for PTSD constitutes a full grant of the benefits sought on appeal with respect to this claim.

ruleID.text: Thus, the grant of service connection for PTSD constitutes a full grant of the benefits sought on appeal with respect to this claim.

rhetClass.text: ORDER

sentences.text: Service connection for PTSD is granted.

rhetClass.text: Service connection for PTSD is granted.

sentences.text: REMAND

rhetClass.text: REMAND

sentences.text: Initially, the Board notes the Veteran indicated at his December 2017 hearing that he continued to receive ongoing medical treatment through VA.

rhetClass.text: Initially, the Board notes the Veteran indicated at his December 2017 hearing that he continued to receive ongoing medical treatment through VA.

sentences.text: See Transcript p.

rhetClass.text: See Transcript p.

sentences.text: Although he stated it was for his psychiatric disorder, the Board cannot preclude the possibility that he was treated for the other conditions that are the focus of this appeal.

rhetClass.text: Although he stated it was for his psychiatric disorder, the Board cannot preclude the possibility that he was treated for the other conditions that are the focus of this appeal.

sentences.text: Relevant statutory and regulatory provisions emphasize the importance of obtaining VA records as part of the duty to assist.

rhetClass.text: Relevant statutory and regulatory provisions emphasize the importance of obtaining VA records as part of the duty to assist.

sentences.text: See 38 U.S.C.A. Â§ 5103A(c)(2); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159(c)(2) ; see also Bell v. Derwinski, 2 Vet. App. 611 (1992); Sullivan v. McDonald, 815 F.3d 786 (Fed. Cir. 2016).

rhetClass.text: See 38 U.S.C.A. Â§ 5103A(c)(2); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159(c)(2) ; see also Bell v. Derwinski, 2 Vet. App. 611 (1992); Sullivan v. McDonald, 815 F.3d 786 (Fed. Cir. 2016).

sentences.text: He also indicated at the hearing that he had private audiograms which demonstrated that his hearing loss satisfied the criteria for a compensable rating.

rhetClass.text: He also indicated at the hearing that he had private audiograms which demonstrated that his hearing loss satisfied the criteria for a compensable rating.

sentences.text: See Transcript pp.

rhetClass.text: See Transcript pp.

sentences.text: Consequently, the Board concludes that it must remand this case in order to obtain any such records.

rhetClass.text: Consequently, the Board concludes that it must remand this case in order to obtain any such records.

sentences.text: As to his claim of service connection for a left hand disability, the Veteran has indicated it was due to an in-service injury; and in the alternate that it is secondary to his service-connected left index finger disability.

rhetClass.text: As to his claim of service connection for a left hand disability, the Veteran has indicated it was due to an in-service injury; and in the alternate that it is secondary to his service-connected left index finger disability.

sentences.text: The Board acknowledges that a June 2009 VA examination diagnosed left hand synovitis.

rhetClass.text: The Board acknowledges that a June 2009 VA examination diagnosed left hand synovitis.

sentences.text: Although the examiner initially stated that an opinion as to whether the synovitis was related to service would be speculative, a subsequent addendum stated it was naturally occurring and was not related to service.

rhetClass.text: Although the examiner initially stated that an opinion as to whether the synovitis was related to service would be speculative, a subsequent addendum stated it was naturally occurring and was not related to service.

sentences.text: However, it does not appear that opinion provided sufficient rationale, nor did it address the issue of secondary service connection.

rhetClass.text: However, it does not appear that opinion provided sufficient rationale, nor did it address the issue of secondary service connection.

sentences.text: Thus, the Board finds that this VA examination is not adequate to resolve the claim of service connection for a left hand disability.

rhetClass.text: Thus, the Board finds that this VA examination is not adequate to resolve the claim of service connection for a left hand disability.

polarity.text: Thus, the Board finds that this VA examination is not adequate to resolve the claim of service connection for a left hand disability.

ruleID.text: Thus, the Board finds that this VA examination is not adequate to resolve the claim of service connection for a left hand disability.

sentences.text: Therefore, the Board finds that a remand is required to accord the Veteran a new examination which does adequately address this claims.

rhetClass.text: Therefore, the Board finds that a remand is required to accord the Veteran a new examination which does adequately address this claims.

sentences.text: See Barr v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 303 (2007); Colvin v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 171, 175 (1991).

rhetClass.text: See Barr v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 303 (2007); Colvin v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 171, 175 (1991).

sentences.text: The examination of the left hand should also include findings as to the current nature and severity of the service-connected left index finger.

rhetClass.text: The examination of the left hand should also include findings as to the current nature and severity of the service-connected left index finger.

sentences.text: Regarding the claim of entitlement to a temporary total rating pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.29, the Board notes that the 2010 period of domiciliary care which is the basis for this claim reflects one of the primary diagnoses for that care was the Veteran's psychiatric disorder.

rhetClass.text: Regarding the claim of entitlement to a temporary total rating pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.29, the Board notes that the 2010 period of domiciliary care which is the basis for this claim reflects one of the primary diagnoses for that care was the Veteran's psychiatric disorder.

sentences.text: As detailed above, the Board has determined service connection is warranted for PTSD.

rhetClass.text: As detailed above, the Board has determined service connection is warranted for PTSD.

polarity.text: As detailed above, the Board has determined service connection is warranted for PTSD.

ruleID.text: As detailed above, the Board has determined service connection is warranted for PTSD.

sentences.text: However, the Board is precluded from assigning the initial rating(s) and effective date(s) for this disability.

rhetClass.text: However, the Board is precluded from assigning the initial rating(s) and effective date(s) for this disability.

sentences.text: Such development may affect the Veteran's entitlement to a total rating under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.29.

rhetClass.text: Such development may affect the Veteran's entitlement to a total rating under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.29.

sentences.text: Similarly, this development, as well as resolution of the other appellate claims, may affect whether the Veteran is entitled to a TDIU.

rhetClass.text: Similarly, this development, as well as resolution of the other appellate claims, may affect whether the Veteran is entitled to a TDIU.

sentences.text: Thus, the Board must defer adjudication of the temporary total rating and TDIU claims until the development deemed necessary for the other claims have been completed.

rhetClass.text: Thus, the Board must defer adjudication of the temporary total rating and TDIU claims until the development deemed necessary for the other claims have been completed.

sentences.text: Accordingly, the case is REMANDED for the following action:

rhetClass.text: Accordingly, the case is REMANDED for the following action:

sentences.text: Expedited handling is requested.)

rhetClass.text: Expedited handling is requested.)

sentences.text: Request the names and addresses of all medical care providers who have treated the Veteran for his left index finger, left hand, and hearing loss since August 2017.

rhetClass.text: Request the names and addresses of all medical care providers who have treated the Veteran for his left index finger, left hand, and hearing loss since August 2017.

sentences.text: Even if the Veteran does not respond, determine if there are any outstanding VA medical records for the pertinent period to include the treatment noted at his December 2017 hearing.

rhetClass.text: Even if the Veteran does not respond, determine if there are any outstanding VA medical records for the pertinent period to include the treatment noted at his December 2017 hearing.

sentences.text: The Veteran should also be requested to provide a release for the private audiograms/audio evaluations he referenced at the December 2017 hearing.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran should also be requested to provide a release for the private audiograms/audio evaluations he referenced at the December 2017 hearing.

sentences.text: After securing any necessary release, obtain those records not on file.

rhetClass.text: After securing any necessary release, obtain those records not on file.

sentences.text: Notify the Veteran that he may submit lay statements from himself and from other individuals who have first-hand knowledge, and/or were contemporaneously informed of his in-service and post-service left hand symptomatology; and the nature, extent and severity of his left index finger and hearing loss symptoms, as well as the impact of these conditions and other service-connected disabilities on his ability to work.

rhetClass.text: Notify the Veteran that he may submit lay statements from himself and from other individuals who have first-hand knowledge, and/or were contemporaneously informed of his in-service and post-service left hand symptomatology; and the nature, extent and severity of his left index finger and hearing loss symptoms, as well as the impact of these conditions and other service-connected disabilities on his ability to work.

sentences.text: The Veteran should be provided an appropriate amount of time to submit this lay evidence.

rhetClass.text: The Veteran should be provided an appropriate amount of time to submit this lay evidence.

sentences.text: After obtaining any additional records to the extent possible, the Veteran should be afforded an examination(s) to evaluate the current severity of his service-connected left index finger, and to determine the nature and etiology of his claimed left hand disability.

rhetClass.text: After obtaining any additional records to the extent possible, the Veteran should be afforded an examination(s) to evaluate the current severity of his service-connected left index finger, and to determine the nature and etiology of his claimed left hand disability.

sentences.text: The claims folder should be made available to the examiner for review before the examination.

rhetClass.text: The claims folder should be made available to the examiner for review before the examination.

sentences.text: For any left hand disability found to be present other than the already service-connected left index finger, the examiner should express an opinion as to whether it is at least as likely as not it was incurred in or otherwise the result of his active service

rhetClass.text: For any left hand disability found to be present other than the already service-connected left index finger, the examiner should express an opinion as to whether it is at least as likely as not it was incurred in or otherwise the result of his active service

sentences.text: If the examiner determines the Veteran has a left hand disability that is not directly related to service, he or she should express an opinion as to whether it is at least as likely as not it was caused or aggravated by his service-connected left index finger disability.

rhetClass.text: If the examiner determines the Veteran has a left hand disability that is not directly related to service, he or she should express an opinion as to whether it is at least as likely as not it was caused or aggravated by his service-connected left index finger disability.

sentences.text: By aggravation, the Board means a permanent increase in severity that is beyond natural progression.

rhetClass.text: By aggravation, the Board means a permanent increase in severity that is beyond natural progression.

sentences.text: A complete rationale for any onion expressed should be provided, to include if the examiner determines an opinion cannot be provided without resort to speculation.

rhetClass.text: A complete rationale for any onion expressed should be provided, to include if the examiner determines an opinion cannot be provided without resort to speculation.

sentences.text: After completing any additional development deemed necessary, to include assigning the initial rating(s) and effective date(s) for the Veteran's PTSD, readjudicate the issues on appeal in light of any additional evidence added to the records assembled for appellate review.

rhetClass.text: After completing any additional development deemed necessary, to include assigning the initial rating(s) and effective date(s) for the Veteran's PTSD, readjudicate the issues on appeal in light of any additional evidence added to the records assembled for appellate review.

sentences.text: If the benefits requested on appeal are not granted to the Veteran's satisfaction, the Veteran and his representative should be furnished a Supplemental Statement of the Case (SSOC), which addresses all of the evidence obtained since these claims were last adjudicated below, and provides an opportunity to respond.

rhetClass.text: If the benefits requested on appeal are not granted to the Veteran's satisfaction, the Veteran and his representative should be furnished a Supplemental Statement of the Case (SSOC), which addresses all of the evidence obtained since these claims were last adjudicated below, and provides an opportunity to respond.

sentences.text: The case should then be returned to the Board for further appellate consideration, if in order.

rhetClass.text: The case should then be returned to the Board for further appellate consideration, if in order.

sentences.text: By this remand, the Board intimates no opinion as to any final outcome warranted.

rhetClass.text: By this remand, the Board intimates no opinion as to any final outcome warranted.

sentences.text: The appellant has the right to submit additional evidence and argument on the matter or matters the Board has remanded.

rhetClass.text: The appellant has the right to submit additional evidence and argument on the matter or matters the Board has remanded.

sentences.text: Kutscherousky v. West, 12 Vet. App. 369 (1999).

rhetClass.text: Kutscherousky v. West, 12 Vet. App. 369 (1999).

sentences.text: This claim must be afforded expeditious treatment.

rhetClass.text: This claim must be afforded expeditious treatment.

sentences.text: The law requires that all claims that are remanded by the Board of Veterans' Appeals or by the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims for additional development or other appropriate action must be handled in an expeditious manner.

rhetClass.text: The law requires that all claims that are remanded by the Board of Veterans' Appeals or by the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims for additional development or other appropriate action must be handled in an expeditious manner.

ruleTree.label: The veteran has a disability that is service-connected.

nodes.label: The veteran has a present disability.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and the veteran presently has a diagnosis of PTSD supported by medical evidence diagnosing the condition in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125(a).
The veteran suffered an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury in line of duty.
The veteran suffered an in-service incurrence of a disease or injury.
The veteran suffered an injury or contracted a disease during active military service.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and there is credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred.
There is adequate evidence that the veteran suffered from the claimed disease or injury while in service.
The injury or disease did not preexist entry into service.
The veteran is presumed to have been in sound condition when examined, accepted, and enrolled for service (the presumption of sound condition or presumption of soundness).

The veteran served in the active military, naval, or air service, during a period of war or after December 31, 1946, and clear and unmistakable evidence demonstrates that the injury or disease existed before acceptance and enrollment and was not aggravated by such service.
The veteran suffered an in-service aggravation of a disease or injury.
The injury or disease preexisted entry into service.
There was an aggravation during service.
The presumption of aggravation has been satisfied.
Based on clear and unmistakable evidence (obvious or manifest) that is undebatable, there is a specific finding that the increase in disability is due to the natural progress of the disease.
The disability is a result of the veteranâ€™s own willful misconduct or abuse of alcohol or drugs.
There is a causal relationship [nexus] between the present disability and the injury, disease, or aggravation of a preexisting injury or disease incurred during active duty.
The veteranâ€™s claim is for PTSD, and there is a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor.

text:
Citation Nr: 1814360	
Decision Date: 03/12/18    Archive Date: 03/19/18

DOCKET NO.  12-00 967	)	DATE
	)
	)

On appeal from the
Department of Veterans Affairs Regional Office in Cleveland, Ohio


THE ISSUES

1.  Entitlement to a rating in excess of 10 percent for service-connected boutonniere deformity of the left index finger.

2.  Entitlement to service connection for a left hand disability, to include as secondary to service-connected left index finger disability.

3.  Entitlement to service connection for an acquired psychiatric disorder, to include posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

4.  Propriety of reduction of service-connected hearing loss from 10 to zero percent, effective May 18, 2010.

5.  Entitlement to a temporary total rating pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.29 for hospitalization in excess of 21 days.

6.  Entitlement to a total rating based upon individual unemployability (TDIU) due to service-connected disability.

REPRESENTATION

Appellant represented by:	The American Legion


WITNESS AT HEARING ON APPEAL

Appellant


ATTORNEY FOR THE BOARD

John Kitlas, Counsel


INTRODUCTION

The record reflects the Veteran served on active duty in the United States Air Force from November 1975 to November 1979.  Further, the record reflects he had additional service in the Reserves.

This matter is before the Board of Veterans' Appeals (Board) on appeal from rating decisions by a Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Regional Office (RO).

This appeal has been advanced on the Board's docket pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 20.900(c) (2017).  38 U.S.C.A. Â§ 7107(a)(2) (West 2014).

The Veteran provided testimony at a hearing before the undersigned Veterans Law Judge (VLJ) in December 2017.  A transcript of that hearing is of record.

For the reasons addressed in the REMAND portion of the decision below, the Board finds that, except for the psychiatric disorder claim, further development is required regarding the Veteran's appellate claims.  Accordingly, these claims are REMANDED to the Agency of Original Jurisdiction (AOJ).
FINDINGS OF FACT

The competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.


CONCLUSION OF LAW

The criteria for a grant of service connection for PTSD are met.  38 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 1110, 1131, 5107 (West 2014); 38 C.F.R. Â§Â§ 3.102, 3.303, 3.304 (2017).


REASONS AND BASES FOR FINDINGS AND CONCLUSION

Establishing service connection generally requires medical or, in certain circumstances, lay evidence of (1) a current disability; (2) an in-service incurrence or aggravation of a disease or injury; and (3) a nexus between the claimed in-service disease or injury and the present disability.  See Davidson v. Shinseki, 581 F.3d 1313 (Fed. Cir. 2009); Hickson v. West, 12 Vet. App. 247, 253 (1999); Caluza v. Brown, 7 Vet. App. 498, 506 (1995), aff'd per curiam, 78 F. 3d 604 (Fed. Cir. 1996) (table).  

In addition to the general rules of service connection noted above, service connection for PTSD requires medical evidence diagnosing the condition in accordance with 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 (a); a link, established by medical evidence, between current symptoms and an in-service stressor; and credible supporting evidence that the claimed in-service stressor occurred. 38 C.F.R. Â§  3.304 (f). Further, 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.125 (a) requires that diagnoses of mental disorders conform to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM).  The law also provides that if the evidence establishes a diagnosis of PTSD during service and the claimed stressor is related to that service, in the absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, and provided that the claimed stressor is consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of the veteran's service, the veteran's lay testimony alone may establish the occurrence of the claimed in-service stressor.  38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.304 (f)(1).

Determinations as to service connection will be based on review of the entire evidence of record, to include all pertinent medical and lay evidence, with due consideration to VA's policy to administer the law under a broad and liberal interpretation consistent with the facts in each individual case.  38 U.S.C.A. Â§ 1154(a); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.303(a).

In this case, the Board acknowledges that an April 2017 VA examination concluded the Veteran does not currently satisfy the DSM criteria for a diagnosis of PTSD.  However, the examiner also stated that the Veteran may have had PTSD in the past.  The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims (Court) held in McClain v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 319 (2007) that the requirement that a claimant have a current disability before service connection may be awarded for that disability is also satisfied when a claimant has a disability at the time a claim for VA disability compensation is filed or during the pendency of that claim, even if no disability is present at the time of the claim's adjudication.  Here, a review of the medical treatment records reflect the Veteran has been diagnosed with PTSD during the pendency of this case, to include in 2010 and 2011.  Moreover, the law mandates resolving all reasonable doubt in favor of the Veteran.  38 U.S.C.A. Â§ 5107; 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.102.

The Board further notes that the Veteran has essentially contended he has PTSD due to the in-service stressors of participating in rescue operations of a crashed airplane, and witnessing the aftermath of the Jonestown massacre.  Regarding these stressors, the record reflects the Veteran was part of the 1550th Organization Maintenance Squadron, 1550 Aircrew Training and Test Wing; which Department of Personnel Records Information Retrieval System (DPRIS) has confirmed did participate in operations consistent with the stressors identified by the Veteran.  Granted, it has been noted that the record does not confirm the Veteran personally participated in either of these operations.  Nevertheless, as he was a member of that group, his purported participation is not incompatible with his military occupational specialty (MOS), and in absence of clear and convincing evidence to the contrary, the Board finds the Veteran's account of such stressors is consistent with the circumstances, conditions, or hardships of his active service.

The Board also acknowledges that the April 2017 VA examiner provided an opinion against the Veteran's current acquired psychiatric disorder being etiologically related to his active service.  However, various medical treatment records indicate otherwise.  In pertinent part, an initial intake assessment for PTSD in December 2011 shows a diagnosis of PTSD, and indicated it was based upon the Veteran's account of the aforementioned stressors.  As such, it appears the competent medical evidence is in equipoise on this matter.  In Gilbert v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 49, 54 (1990), the Court stated that in light of the benefit of the doubt doctrine, the question is whether the evidence supports the claim or is in relative equipoise, with the claimant prevailing in either event.  

In view of the foregoing, the Board finds the competent medical and other evidence of record reflects it is at least as likely as not the Veteran currently has PTSD as a result of his active service.  Therefore, service connection is warranted.

The Board acknowledges that the Veteran has received various diagnoses for his acquired psychiatric disorder in addition to PTSD, to include mood disorder, adjustment disorder, and depressive disorder; and the law does not preclude establishing service connection for a separately diagnosed acquired psychiatric disorder.  See Clemons v. Shinseki, 23 Vet. App. 1 (2009).  However, based upon review of the treatment records associated with the diagnosis of PTSD, the Board finds this condition encompasses the scope of the Veteran's psychiatric symptomatology.  Thus, the grant of service connection for PTSD constitutes a full grant of the benefits sought on appeal with respect to this claim.


ORDER

Service connection for PTSD is granted.


REMAND

Initially, the Board notes the Veteran indicated at his December 2017 hearing that he continued to receive ongoing medical treatment through VA.  See Transcript p. 11.  Although he stated it was for his psychiatric disorder, the Board cannot preclude the possibility that he was treated for the other conditions that are the focus of this appeal.  Relevant statutory and regulatory provisions emphasize the importance of obtaining VA records as part of the duty to assist.  See 38 U.S.C.A. Â§ 5103A(c)(2); 38 C.F.R. Â§ 3.159(c)(2) ; see also Bell v. Derwinski, 2 Vet. App. 611 (1992); Sullivan v. McDonald, 815 F.3d 786 (Fed. Cir. 2016).  He also indicated at the hearing that he had private audiograms which demonstrated that his hearing loss satisfied the criteria for a compensable rating.  See Transcript pp. 5-6.  Consequently, the Board concludes that it must remand this case in order to obtain any such records.

As to his claim of service connection for a left hand disability, the Veteran has indicated it was due to an in-service injury; and in the alternate that it is secondary to his service-connected left index finger disability.  The Board acknowledges that a June 2009 VA examination diagnosed left hand synovitis.  Although the examiner initially stated that an opinion as to whether the synovitis was related to service would be speculative, a subsequent addendum stated it was naturally occurring and was not related to service.  However, it does not appear that opinion provided sufficient rationale, nor did it address the issue of secondary service connection.  Thus, the Board finds that this VA examination is not adequate to resolve the claim of service connection for a left hand disability.  Therefore, the Board finds that a remand is required to accord the Veteran a new examination which does adequately address this claims.  See Barr v. Nicholson, 21 Vet. App. 303 (2007); Colvin v. Derwinski, 1 Vet. App. 171, 175 (1991).  The examination of the left hand should also include findings as to the current nature and severity of the service-connected left index finger.  

Regarding the claim of entitlement to a temporary total rating pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.29, the Board notes that the 2010 period of domiciliary care which is the basis for this claim reflects one of the primary diagnoses for that care was the Veteran's psychiatric disorder.  As detailed above, the Board has determined service connection is warranted for PTSD.  However, the Board is precluded from assigning the initial rating(s) and effective date(s) for this disability.  Such development may affect the Veteran's entitlement to a total rating under 38 C.F.R. Â§ 4.29.  Similarly, this development, as well as resolution of the other appellate claims, may affect whether the Veteran is entitled to a TDIU.  Thus, the Board must defer adjudication of the temporary total rating and TDIU claims until the development deemed necessary for the other claims have been completed.

Accordingly, the case is REMANDED for the following action:

(Please note, this appeal has been advanced on the Board's docket pursuant to 38 C.F.R. Â§ 20.900(c).  Expedited handling is requested.)

1.  Request the names and addresses of all medical care providers who have treated the Veteran for his left index finger, left hand, and hearing loss since August 2017.  Even if the Veteran does not respond, determine if there are any outstanding VA medical records for the pertinent period to include the treatment noted at his December 2017 hearing.

The Veteran should also be requested to provide a release for the private audiograms/audio evaluations he referenced at the December 2017 hearing.

After securing any necessary release, obtain those records not on file.

2.  Notify the Veteran that he may submit lay statements from himself and from other individuals who have first-hand knowledge, and/or were contemporaneously informed of his in-service and post-service left hand symptomatology; and the nature, extent and severity of his left index finger and hearing loss symptoms, as well as the impact of these conditions and other service-connected disabilities on his ability to work.  The Veteran should be provided an appropriate amount of time to submit this lay evidence. 

3.  After obtaining any additional records to the extent possible, the Veteran should be afforded an examination(s) to evaluate the current severity of his service-connected left index finger, and to determine the nature and etiology of his claimed left hand disability.  The claims folder should be made available to the examiner for review before the examination.

For any left hand disability found to be present other than the already service-connected left index finger, the examiner should express an opinion as to whether it is at least as likely as not it was incurred in or otherwise the result of his active service

If the examiner determines the Veteran has a left hand disability that is not directly related to service, he or she should express an opinion as to whether it is at least as likely as not it was caused or aggravated by his service-connected left index finger disability.  By aggravation, the Board means a permanent increase in severity that is beyond natural progression.

A complete rationale for any onion expressed should be provided, to include if the examiner determines an opinion cannot be provided without resort to speculation.

4.  After completing any additional development deemed necessary, to include assigning the initial rating(s) and effective date(s) for the Veteran's PTSD, readjudicate the issues on appeal in light of any additional evidence added to the records assembled for appellate review.  If the benefits requested on appeal are not granted to the Veteran's satisfaction, the Veteran and his representative should be furnished a Supplemental Statement of the Case (SSOC), which addresses all of the evidence obtained since these claims were last adjudicated below, and provides an opportunity to respond.  

The case should then be returned to the Board for further appellate consideration, if in order.  By this remand, the Board intimates no opinion as to any final outcome warranted.

The appellant has the right to submit additional evidence and argument on the matter or matters the Board has remanded.  Kutscherousky v. West, 12 Vet. App. 369 (1999).

This claim must be afforded expeditious treatment.  The law requires that all claims that are remanded by the Board of Veterans' Appeals or by the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims for additional development or other appropriate action must be handled in an expeditious manner.  See 38 U.S.C.A. Â§Â§ 5109B, 7112 (West 2014).




______________________________________________
STEVEN D. REISS
Veterans Law Judge, Board of Veterans' Appeals

Department of Veterans Affairs
